This version was derived from Guide to Records-Jamaic-PC.docNew York University ArchivesThis finding aid was produced using ArchivesSpace 2022-01-18T20:57:00Description is in English. Materials are in English.
New York University Archives
Records of the Jamaica Peace Corps Training Program
Rubin, Vera D.
RISM.RG.6
22 boxes
1961-1982 1962 In 1961 the Research Institute for the Study of Man (RISM) was contracted to train volunteers for the United States Peace Corps. Transferred to the Caribbean, the volunteers assisted the Jamaican government by training workers in librarianship, industrial arts, nursing and vocational education. The collection, which reflects the early years of the Peace Corps, and RISM's specialized knowledge of the Caribbean, includes correspondence, financial records, teaching papers, training guides, clippings, photographs, print material, reports, cassette tapes, and compact discs. Materials are stored offsite and advance notice is required for use. Please request materials at least two business days prior to your research visit to coordinate access.
Provenance
The records of the Peace Corps Training Program were generated by Dr. Vera D. Rubin (1911 - 1985), Director of the Research Institute for The Study of Man (RISM) and her staff in fulfillment of a contract with The U.S. Peace Corps.
Processing Information
The collection was processed by Emilyn L. Brown between Mar - Apr 2007
Conditions Governing Access
The collection is open for research with the exception of part or all of Series III, IV, V, and IX, which are restricted.
Conditions Governing Use
Permission to publish materials must be obtained in writing from the: >New York University Archives; Elmer Holmes Bobst Library, 70 Washington Square South, New York, NY 10012. Phone: (212) 998-2646; Fax: (212) 995-4225; E-mail:university-archives@nyu.edu
Preferred Citation
Published citations should take the following form:
Identification of item, date (if known); The Records of the Peace Corps Training Program; RG 6; box number; folder number;
Research Institute for the Study of Man/New York University Archives
Historical Note
On March 1, 1961, President John F. Kennedy established the U.S. Peace Corps to promote international peace efforts through volunteer workers. Based on its specialization in Caribbean research, the Research Institute for the Study of Man (RISM) was selected to train Peace Corps volunteers to assist and support the vocational adult education programs sponsored by the government in Jamaica, West Indies.
The initial phase of the training program was conducted between April 2 - May 31, 1962 with Peace Corps volunteers housed at the International House situated on the Columbia University campus. Dr. Vera Rubin served as a consultant for the program, which was co-directed by Drs. Lambros Comitas and Robert Stigler. Course work included Caribbean (area) studies, American studies and world affairs, technical and agricultural training, commerce, industrial arts and health care. Noted anthropologists Sidney Mintz, David Lowenthal, M.G. Smith and others gave lectures. Many individuals involved in public service provided lectures for the American Affairs unit, notably Dean Acheson, U.S. Secretary of State from 1949 - 1953, Zbigniew K. Brzezinski, and Adlai E. Stevenson.
The Program's field trips and extra-curricular activities included a visit to Hyde Park, New York, where volunteers spoke with Mrs. Eleanor Roosevelt, attending the birthday party of President John F. Kennedy at Madison Square Garden in New York City and visits to the Library of Congress in Washington, D.C.
During the second phase of the training program, volunteers received additional instruction and orientation to the region at the University College of the West Indies (UCWI) at Mona, Jamaica, W.I. Approximately 30 Peace Corps volunteers were assigned to diverse institutions, including youth camps at Chestervald and Cobbla, Regional Trade Training Centers, Teacher Training Colleges that included the Mico Training College for Teachers, the Shortwood Training College for Women Teachers, and at Frome Senior High Schools, Holmwood Technical School in Manchester, Vere Technical School in Clarendon and technical institutes in Port Antonio and Montego Bay. Their work responsibilities included teaching industrial arts, vocational skills, commercial bookeeping, chemistry, biology and physics. Other volunteers worked as nurse-educators, participated in agricultural projects or assisted the Jamaican Library Service, and the University College of the West Indies with cataloguing and classification.
Scope and Contents
The records of the Jamaica Peace Corps Training Program document the activities of the U.S. Peace Corps, and the Research Institute for the Study of Man (RISM) from the 1960s through the 1980s. The bulk of the collection, which consists of 21 boxes and approximately 12 linear feet, documents the actual training program, which was conducted between April - May 1962. The materials generated during the course of the Program are mainly textual in nature comprising correspondence between the U.S. Peace Corps, staff and faculty members, and Dr. Vera Rubin. Other textual documents include program guides, which outline the goals and objectives of setting up a training program and includes RISM's own training proposal. Syllabai and teaching papers, publications, clippings, maps, reports and print materials associated with the Program's graduation ceremony are also included.
Other formats in the collection are individual and group photographs of the Peace Corps Volunteers, and tickets from the birthday celebrtion organized for John F. Kennedy at Madison Square Garden. Audiovisual materials include a film reel of the volunteer's visit to Mrs. Eleanor Roosevelt, audiocassettes and reel-to-reel tapes of the Jamaican Language Guide by Mrs. Beryl Bailey, class lectures, and the Graduation ceremony. Note: Several series pertaining to the Peace Corps volnteers are restricted due to the sensitive nature of the materials and privacy of individuals. These series are as follows: Series III. Volunteer Registration Records, Series IV. Health Services, Series V. Volunteer Evaluation, and Series IX. Volunteer Files.
Arrangement
The papers of the Jamaica Peace Corps. Project are arranged as # series, and some further arranged as subseries. The contents of each series or subseries is arranged chronologically with the exception of Series V, Volunteer Records, which is arranged alphabetically.
The files are grouped into 19 series:
Series
I. Correspondence
II. Peace Corps Program Development
III. Volunteer Registration Records [Restricted]
IV. Program Health Services [Restricted]
V. Volunteer Evaluation Records [Restricted]
VI. Program Administration Records
VII. Teaching Papers
VIII. Field Trips and Extra-Curricular Activities
IX. Volunteer Files [Restricted]
X. Regional Placement Records
XI. Photographs
XII. Public Relations
XIII. Clippings
XIV. Audiovisual Materials
XV. Maps
XVI. Peace Corps Graduation Ceremony
XVII. Peace Corps Volunteer Publications
XVIII. Final Reports
XIX. Miscellaneous Papers
Related Material
The Vera Rubin Papers, RG 1 (at RISM)
At NYU:
Study of the Aspirations of Youth in a Developing Country (The Trinidad Study), RISM RG 5
Attitudes of Medical Students, RISM RG 7
Inter-University Consortium, RISM RG 9
Separated Material
There is no information about materials that are associated by provenance to the described materials that have been physically separated or removed.

Series I. Correspondence
Scope and Contents note
1.0 linear feet (2 boxes) arranged chronologically. The correspondence series, which contains incoming and outgoing letters, documents the early relationship between the U.S. Peace Corps and the Research Institute for the Study of Man (RISM). The bulk of material was generated between March - April of 1962, and relates specifically to the training curriculum for Peace Corps Volunteers (PCV). Notable correspondents include Seargent Shriver, director of the Peace Corps, the Honorable Norman W. Manley, Beryl Bailey, H.D. Huggins and other faculty members of the University College of the West Indies (UCWI). Letters establishing potential placement, recruitment of training personnel and forms letters to new volunteers are also included.Correspondence1961 December11Correspondence1962 January12Correspondence, draft program timetable1962 February13Correspondence, notes1962 February14Correspondence, telegram, notes1962 March15Peace Corps Volunteer lists, welcome letters1962 March16Correspondence1962 March17Correspondence1962 March18Correspondence1962 April19Correspondence1962 April 110Correspondence, notes1962 April 111Correspondence, telegrams, notes, ephemera1962 April112Correspondence1962 May 113Correspondence1962 May 114Correspondence1962 May, undated115Correspondence1962 June 21Correspondence, notes1962 June, undated22Correspondence1962 July 23Correspondence, concert flyer1962 August24Correspondence, list of telegrams and cables1962 November, undated25Series II. Peace Corps Program Development
Scope and Contents note
1.25 linear feet (2.5 boxes) arranged chronologically. This series contains national and international Peace Corps programs that provide an overview of the goals and principles of the agency. Other materials include the Peace Corps Fact Book, instructional handbooks, syllabi, training reports, testing requirements, project descriptions, and related correspondence and memorandum, which were used in the development of RISM's training program (see Series VI).Handbook for Foreign Student Advisers, Part VI. Volunteer Registration Records [Some material restricted]
Scope and Contents note
.5 linear feet (1 box), arranged chronologically. This series documents the registration process and includes correspondence, questionnaires, volunteer lists, Peace Corps brochures, instructions, forms, and print material from International House where volunteers resided during their training. Because of the sensitive nature of material that appears on the registration forms, folders 13 and 14 are restricted.Peace Corps Background Information Form1961 June48Personal Interview Records [blank]1961 August49Instructions for Completing Form PC-52 Notice of Volunteers Registered for Training1961 September410Personal History Blanks1961 September411Annual Report, forms for International House, notes1961 November412Project Invitation Summary Sheets, correspondence with Peace Corps questionnaire1962 February-March 416The Peace Corps FactBook, forms, instructions1962 March417Registration Data Sheets A - K1962 March418Registration Data Sheets L - Z1962 March419Jamaica Instructions for Reporting to the Peace Corps Reception Center, International House, New York1962 March420U.S. Civil Service Commission Fingerprint Charts, volunteer identification card numbers1962 March54International House brochures, room assignments, instructions, memorandum, notes1962 March-April55Series IV. Program Health Services [RESTRICTED]
Scope and Contents note
approximately .5 linear feet (1 box), arranged chronologically. The papers in this series, which relate to the health and well being of Peace Corps volunteers, include brochures, medical budgets, correspondence, medical reports and summaries. Because of the sensitive nature of the material, the entire series is restricted.Series V. Volunteer Evaluation Forms [RESTRICTED]
Scope and Contents note
.5 liner feet (1 box), arranged chronologically. This series mainly consists of personal interviews, psychiatric evaluations, and self-evaluation forms for volunteers. Correspondence, articles, reports, statistical summary cards and notes are also included. Because of the sensitive nature of the papers, the entire series is restricted.Series VI. Program Administration Records
Scope and Contents note
.5 linear feet (1 box), arranged chronologically. The papers in this series document the organization and day-to-day operations of the Jamaica Peace Corps Training Program. Included are program proposals, curriculum vitae for staff and faculty, program schedules, syllabi, correspondence, general reading lists, and notes (see Series VII. Teaching Papers for specific subject curriculum).Proposal for a Peace Corps Training Program, Contract Article I - Definitions, Article II - General Scope of the Program, draft chart, notes1961 December610Proposal for a Peace Corps Training Program [original typescript]1961 December611List of Program staff and faculty1962 February-March612Curriculum vitae for staff and faculty, A - B1962 February-March613Curriculum vitae for staff and faculty, C1962 February-March614Curriculum vitae for staff and faculty, D - L1962 February-March615Curriculum vitae for staff and faculty, O - S1962 February-March616Curriculum vitae for Mottram Torres1962 February-March617Correspondence, curriculum vitae for staff and faculty U - Z, staff and faculty telephone address list, notes1962 February-March618Draft progam charts, notes1962 March619Draft daily schedules [draft], notes1962 March620Final daily schedules1962 March621Notes1962 March-May622Series VII. Teaching Papers
Scope and Contents note
Two linear feet (4 boxes), arranged chronologically. This series highlights the academic and technical training taught in the program. These training materials have been organized as five subseries: Subseries A. Peace Corps Orientation, Program Syllabi, and Area Studies, on the history, geography and culture of Jamaica, W.I., including the original typescript, A Language Guide toJamaica, written by Beryl Bailey. Note: Recorded versions of this guide can be found in Series XIV, Audio-visual Materials. The papers in Subseries B. Technical Studies, relate to studies in the industrial arts, vocational education, biological science, agriculture, library science, nursing, plumbing, auto mechanics and other trades. Subseries C. American Studies and World Affairs focused on communism and other newsworthy events during the 1960s. The papers in Subseries D. Health Training, mainly relate to public health education. Subseries E. Physical Education relates to physical fitness soccer, cricket and other sports activities.Subseries A. Physical EducationCorrespondence, notes, ephemera1962 March-April105Instructions for playing cricket1962 April-May106Article, ephemera1962 April-May107Physical fitness index scores; grade scores1962 April-May108Series VIII. Field Trips and Special Events
Scope and Contents note
8 folders, arranged chronologically. This series documents the various field trips and extra-curricular activities organized on behalf of the Peace Corps volunteers. Highlights of this series include correspondence between Dr. Rubin and Mrs. Eleanor Roosevelt regarding a visit to Hyde Park, letters to Adelai Stevenson, at the United Nations, and the volunteers visit to highly publicized birthday rally held for President John F. Kennedy at Madison Square Garden in New York City. Volunteers also visited major libraries, the New Jersey Department of Labor and Agriculture, and toured Washington, D.C.Field trip schedules and agendas1962 March-April109Correspondence related to Hyde Park visit1962 March-April1010Correspondence for United Nations visit1962 March-April1011Correspondence, agenda for Washington, D.C. tour1962 April1012Correspondence National Arts Club1962 April-May1013Correspondence Radio Music City Hall1962 April-May1014Correspondence, agenda for visit to N.J. Dept. of Labor and Agriculture, notes1962 May 1015Correspondence Annual Dance, Caribbean Federation for Mental Health1962 May 1016Correspondence and agenda for various library visits1962 May 1017Correspondence, ticket for Madison Square Birthday Rally held for President John F. Kennedy1962 May 1018Agenda, brochure on West Indian dance, notes1962 May 1019Directions to Manhattan sites, visitors guide, Columbia University Student Handbook, miscellaneous papers1962 May 1020Series IX. Volunteer Files [RESTRICTED]
Scope and Contents note
1.0 linear feet (2 boxes) arranged alphabetically. This is a restricted series that contains individual volunteer files consisting of biographical data, self-evaluation inventories, confidential reports, test booklets, personal interviews, profile and case summaries, test scores, assessment summaries, and essays. There are also volunteer evaluations of the Peace Corps Training Program.Series X. Volunteer Placement Records
Scope and Contents note
Approximately .75 linear feet (1 box), arranged chronologically. This series documents volunteer placement by region and area of study, selective service status where applicable, and other items effecting their assignments. Also included are numerous forms issued by the Peace Corps, correspondence, memorandum, passport and visa applications and instructions, suggestions for clothing and miscellaneous papers.Report of Final Selection Board forms, volunteer placement lists by region and area of study1962 May 137Correspondence Office of Selection, volunteer placement lists by region; volunteer lists1962 May 138Memorandum Concerning [Military] Selective Service and Reserve Obligations1962 May 139Memorandum on Moratorium for National Defense Student Loans, Selective Service Status of Volunteers forms1962 May 1310Peer Nomination Forms1962 May 1311Correspondence, clothing suggestions for Jamaica, W.I.1962 May 1312Clothing suggestions for Peace Corp Projects in Brazil and El Salvador1962 May 1313Abstract on transistor radios1962 May 1314Information for Jamaican, W.I. visas1962 May 1315Passport Application forms and instructions1962 May 1316Instructions, Notice of Termination of Volunteer in Training forms, notes1962 May 1317Instructions and Application to Withdraw Termination Payments, notes1962 May 1318Memorandum, forms and correspondence concerning to departure and home leave1962 May 1319Volunteer shipping requests, notes1962 May 1320Series XI. Photographs
Scope and Contents note
1 vol., contents arranged alphabetically by volunteer's last name. The binder contains original and Xeroxed group photos (8 x 10). Two photographs (5 x 7) of each volunteer are consecutively numbered and lettered "a" and "b." The binder also contains a photograph of Herbert L. Wright, Youth Secretary of the National Association for the Advancement of Colored People. Wright was one of several lecturers for the Area Studies component of the Peace Corps Training Program. Invoices, notes and miscellaneous papers related to the photographs are also included.Peace Corps Group Photograph taken by Alex Aster [original]1962 April-May13aPeace Corps Group Photograph [photocopy]1962 April-May13aGrp p/cBraidic, Anthony1962 April-May13a1 a/bBrunelli, Roger1962 April-May13a2 a/bBryan, Sam1962 April-May13a3 a/bCase, Charles1962 April-May13a4 a/bCornelius, Lloyd1962 April-May13a5 a/bDoherty, James1962 April-May 13a6 a/bDuba, Betty1962 April-May 13a7 a/bEarnshaw, Janet1962 April-May 13a8 a/bGarner, Johnnie1962 April-May 13a9 a/bGibbs, Kenneth1962 April-May 13a10 a/bGrobe, Richard1962 April-May 13a11 a/bGrobe, Ruby1962 April-May 13a12 a/bHarris, Daniel1962 April-May 13a13 a/bHarvey, John1962 April-May 13a14 a/bHenderson, John1962 April-May 13a15 a/bHouse, Hugh1962 April-May 13a16 a/bHughes, Barbara F.1962 April-May 13a17 a/bJones, Anthony1962 April-May 13a18 a/bKite, Kenneth1962 April-May 13a19 a/bLathan, Thoyd1962 April-May 13a20 a/bLudin, Philip1962 April-May 13a21 a/bMayeda, Yutaka1962 April-May 13a22 a/bMurphy, Joseph1962 April-May13a23 a/bNolting, Barbara1962 April-May13a24 a/bO'Brien, Robert1962 April-May 13a25 a/bQuanbeck, Fay1962 April-May 13a26 a/bRagsdale, Robert1962 April-May 13a27 a/bRagsdale, Winifred1962 April-May 13a28 a/bRobertson, William1962 April-May 13a29 a/bRoss, Robert1962 April-May 13a30 a/bSchnebel, Carol1962 April-May 13a31 a/bSharman, Benjamin1962 April-May 13a32 a/bSmith, Marvin1962 April-May 13a33 a/bSmith, Virginia1962 April-May 13a34 a/bTanaka, Elsie1962 April-May 13a35 a/bVillicana, Rita1962 April-May 13a36 a/bVincent, Walter1962 April-May 13a37 a/bVogel, Arnold1962 April-May 13a38 a/bWilliams, William M.1962 April-May 13a39 a/bWilmoth, Stephen1962 April-May 13a40 a/bYoung, Pauline1962 April-May 13a41 a/bWright, Herbert L., Youth Secretary, NAACP [See box 11, folder 451962 April-May 13a42Series XII. Public Relations
Scope and Contents note
6 folders, arranged chronologically. The papers in this series were created to promote the Peace Corps Training Program. Included are press releases, correspondence announcements, media interviews and broadcasts. See also Series XIV. Audiovisual Materials.Draft copy, press release announcement of Jamaica Peace Corps Training Program1962 April-May141Press Release announcement1962 March-April142Press Release announcement (revised)1962 March-April143Correspondence, notes regarding volunteer radio and television interviews1962 April-June144List of radio and television and coverage of the program in New York, draft statement describing press coverage in the Jamaica Daily Gleaner and the Peace Corps Training graduation ceremonies described in the New York Times 1962 May-June145Announcement of Peace Corps Training Program graduation broadcast on The Listener's Digest, WRUL1962 May-June146Series XIII. Clippings
Scope and Contents note
Approximately 2.0 linear feet (2 boxes), contents arranged chronologically. This series is comprised of newspaper clippings. Although some clippings relate to the Peace Corps Program and its volunteers, other clippings describe issues in the Caribbean, the U.S. Civil Rights movement, and communism, some of which were most likely used in teaching. Times1962 June153Series XIV. Maps, oversized illustrations
Scope and Contents note
1.0 linear feet (1 oversized box). This series contains oversized maps and illustrations, used to support the coursework and technical training taught in the Peace Corps Training Program, particularly area studies, geography and agricultural skills. Some illustrations relate to the volunteers' specific assignments.British Caribbean Colonies, color print map by Leo Vernon, distributed by British Information Services1948161Two hand drawn maps of Cousins Cove, Pedro Pen and surrounding areaundated162Details of regional placement based on map; two survey maps of Jamaica, W.I.undated163Illustrations of various canoesundated164Illustration of fish potundated165Unidentified regional mapundated166Various road maps of Jamaicaundated167Peace Corps Newspaper Clippings, Oversized1962 June168Unprocessed maps1940-19713Series XV. Audiovisual Materials
Scope and Contents note
(1 record carton). This series consists of reel-to-reel audio and visual recordings of the Jamaica Peace Corps training activities. The tapes includes lectures, the graduation ceremony, volunteer interviews, and a visit with Mrs. Franklin Roosevelt at Hyde Park, New York. Several recordings in this series, which were transferred to CD/DVD format, have been appended to the collection.Subseries A. Appended materialsTwo compact disc copies of Louise Bennett perforance at the Peace Corps graduation ceremonycuid19undated17Series XVI. Peace Corps Graduation Ceremony
Scope and Contents note
.5 linear feet (1 box), arranged chronologically. This series documents the planning activities leading up to the graduation ceremony held for Peace Corps Volunteers. The papers include correspondence, invitations, programs, diplomas and related material.Correspondence, includes telegram from Robert Sargent Shriver, Jr.1962 May 181International House Booking Charge Sheets, stage and seating diagram, notes1962 May 182Graduation ceremony invitations1962 May 183Graduation programs, notes1962 May 184Graduation programs1962 May 185Graduation programs1962 May 186Graduation programs1962 May 187Graduation programs1962 May 188Diplomas [blank]1962 May 189Diplomas [blank]1962 May 1810Diplomas [blank]1962 May 1811Diplomas [blank]1962 May 1812Diplomas [void copies not used -- inscribed with volunteer names]1962 May 1813Diplomas [void copies not used -- inscribed with volunteer names]1962 May 1814Series XVII. Peace Corps Volunteer Publications
Scope and Contents note
.5 linear feet (1 box), arranged chronologically. This series contains newsletters organized by or published for Peace Corps volunteers. The newsletters provide details of various Peace Corps projects, including the activities of graduates from the Jamaica Peace Corps Training Program.Peace Corps News, Vol. 1, No. 11961 June191Peace Corps News, Vol. 2, No. 21962 February192Peace Corps News, Vol. 2, No. 31962 March193The Monthly Eye1962 April-May194The Monthly Eye1962 April-May195The Monthly Eye1962 April-May196Peace Corps News, Vol. 2, No. 41962 May 197The Bull Sheet1963 March198Peace Corps Newsletter1965 March-April199The Peace Corps in Jamaica1982 March1910The Peace Corps in Belize1982 December1911Series XVIII. Final Reports
Scope and Contents note
.5 linear feet (1 box), arranged chronologically. This series contains correspondence, draft outlines, grading forms and reports submitted by Program faculty and medical consultants.
